Message.Title: I thought this was a Microsoft board but I must be wrong
Message.Msg: I thought this was a Microsoft board but I must be wrong as it seems people are talking about politics rather than Microsoft. I also thought that with the departure of Sinofsky, there would be lots of discussion topics around what is going on after the intro of Surface and windows 8 for one of the top executive behind such products to leave so soon after their intro but doesn't seem to bother any one on this Board just talking about Republicans versus Democrats !!! Is the future of Microsoft of any concern for people on this board ? People have been saying that Ballmer is finally betting his job on those products, so does it mean that Ballmer will finally be asked by a very weak Board of Directors to leave the company after having destroyed so much value during his tenure. He also lost a lot of talents with all those Executives leaving one after the other mainly because they were tired of working for him even if in his mind I am sure that he thinks that he is the one who wanted them to leave ! Again I always thought that Microsoft was a great company with lost of talents and resources under one single company, Bill Gates is a great visionary and strategist as he predicted the iPad, the iPhone, the power of a good search engine, the cloud, etc but sadly enough Microsoft was weak on the operational/implementation side and other companies like Apple and Google made this vision happen. Who is to be blamed but the man in charge of such operations for over 10 years, the CEO. Ballmer has never been a great visionary or strategist, with Bill not around anymore and with the people Bill had managed to attrack and put in place when he left to fill the gap,not being there anymore, who is now driving the vision and strategy at Microsoft ? These are the questions I would like to see people on this board debate not the post mortem of a Presidential election.

Message.Title: Ohio food stamp recipients to be cut $50 a month
Message.Msg: I found this enlightening comment by a black man respoding to the above cuts. Made my day. Marshawn HogansI find this funny that once you cut into entitlements it is always doom and gloom. When Americans REALLY suffer i.e Sandy, they are considered resilient and can bounce back. Average Americans went through some kind of loss through the recession and have bounced back in some kind of way. Are you saying $50.00 dollars will kill people? I believe it will change their spending habits yes. Sometimes that is needed. The problem is this. There is no proof that entitlement spending corrects poverty. It only increases it. It causes dependency among low income families. It is worse under Obama's Administration by removing the "will to work" policies that Clinton instilled in the welfare program during his administration. The very fact that Democrats would be willing to increase taxes during an unsettled economy is beyond my bel...ief and studies of economics. The fact is this. If we increase taxes, this will not help the situation. Democrats always find new ways to spend it instead of hitting the root cause for it. You can blame Republicans for being greedy all you want but the real problem is spending. I say give the Democrats what they want to prove a point. True conservatives will know what to do with their money once this happens. We can make money from the move. Once the troops that they rallied begin to fall a part and see that choosing a Prom King was not such a good idea, then they will be willing to listen to conservative solutions. I love my country and would not want to see people fall. But sometimes you have to offer tough love like we do our children and let them experience failure at its best.

Topic.Title: Which stocks Billionaires Love?

Message.Msg: "This is shocking news. This is very surprising," said Brendan Barnicle, an analyst at Pacific Crest Securities. "Like a lot of people, I thought Sinofsky was in line to potentially be Ballmer's successor."

Message.Title: Steven Sinofsky Resigns!
Message.Msg: The exit of 23-year veteran Steven Sinofsky, head of Microsoft's Windows unit, is the latest - and most prominent - in a line of high-profile departures from the Redmond, Washington-based company, which is struggling to keep pace with Apple Inc and Google Inc in mobile computing. It comes hard on the heels of Sinofsky unveiling the most radical revamp of Windows since 1995, designed to catapult Microsoft back into the forefront of Internet-based, touch-screen technology and reinvigorate a stock price that has been static for the past decade. The move was unexpected and neither Microsoft nor Sinofsky gave an explanation, although an executive at the company, who asked not to be named, said the decision was "mutual" and said he was not expecting Sinofsky to take a job at another company soon.

Topic.Title: MSFT Chart Update

Message.Msg: I covered my shorts in MSFT at 26.88. Profit on the trade of $408 per 100 shares (2 mentions) minus commissions. The stock gapped down today based on the resignation of Sinofsky who is/was the overseer of the Windows 8 that was just released. Windows 8 has met with mixed reviews and it is not likely it will be a big money winner for the company. The stock could, and probably will, head lower. Nonetheless, there are chart reasons to take profits here as the 200-week MA is at 26.55, the stock has a strong breakaway gap between 26.12 and 26.39 and does have a mountain of congestion support between 24.25 and 27.50, meaning that squeezing more profit out of this trade is going to be like pulling teeth. There are other stocks where faster and more secure profits can be generated. I will consider shorting the stock again around the 27.50 level but not for another few days and even then the risk/reward ratio is not going to be great.

Topic.Title: For Business, Windows 8 Can Wait

Message.Msg: W7 will be the last non-touch OS. The long term move is clearly to touch screens and W8 will likely be the base for that future. Some companies that are on the leading (and possibly bleeding edge) will go to W8 so that the interface on all their devices (phones, tablets, PCs, etc) is the same. It's a solid move by MSFT but let's face it, this company isn't in an explosive growth phase and hasn't been for many a year. Good solid company that will continue to provide decent returns.

Topic.Title: Microsoft's Windows head, once a possible CEO, exits

Message.Msg: " If so, does that bode well or ill for the future of Microsoft?" Now that is a truly interesting question, one that begs a multitude of possible scenarios. At some time in the future Ballmer will either retire voluntarily or be forcibly put out to pasture by the board. Could he be secretly cultivating someone inside already for his eventual stepping down? Who from the outside is available and prepared to step in and take the helm of a drifting ship with a worn and threadbare brand to put it right in the water again? What might either of those people bring to the table, what new ideas, what fresh approaches to a mature PC environment? Phone market? Tablet market? Which would be better, an insider with a large amount of accumulated institutional knowledge and intimate familiarity with internal processes, communication channels and personnel capabilities or an outsider with untainted vision? I'd be interested in reading some thoughtful discussion on these questions.

Message.Title: Windows 8 vs Linux
Message.Msg: Windows 8 boots in 40 seconds on my laptop. That same laptop only takes 15 seconds to boot into Linux. Windows 8 has the lame Metro tile interface and everything is hidden. Hate it. Linux has a traditional desktop interface without tiles. In fact, Linux offers at least 7 different graphical interfaces you can chose from. You have to pay for Windows 8, but Linux is free. In fact, I'm using my Linux laptop to type this right now. It has an AMD dual core processor, 8gb of RAM, a Samsung SSD and NO WinTel Inside!

Topic.Title: Windows 8 vs Linux

Message.Msg: You do have Intel inside since AMD licenses Intel's x86 architecture for their CPU's. However, with respect to the comparison of W8 vs Linux, you are correct on most points. Unlike the Microsoft approach which attempts to force everyone into a tile-driven environment that looks like it was created as an elementary school project, Linux gives users complete flexibility and choice to chose what interface they like, and Linux doesn't push paid advertisements to its apps like Microsoft does without the user's knowledge. W8 is all about what's good for Microsoft. Microsoft threw PC users under the bus.

Topic.Title: Windows 8 vs Linux

Message.Msg: It doesn't matter if AMD sold its fabs. The CPU's AMD sells use the Intel instruction set designed by Intel. It is well documented that Intel's CPU's outperform AMD's in both absolute performance and performance per Watt, so Lintel delivers the best overall performance. But one thing for sure, W8 is the best thing that ever happened to Linux.
